title: 110_s3228
content: Tax credit for green roofs. Tax credit for green roofs. Congress finds that green roofs reduce stormwater runoff, heating and cooling loads, filter pollutants and carbon dioxide from the air, filter pollutants and heavy metals from rainwater, and have the potential to reduce the size of HVAC equipment and standard insulation, resulting in cost savings. Green roofs offer various benefits such as reducing sewage system loads, absorbing air pollution, protecting roof material, reducing noise transfer, insulating buildings, and providing habitat for beneficial insects and animals. The purpose of encouraging the construction of green roofs is to reduce rooftop temperatures, decrease indoor temperatures, lessen pressure on sewer systems, filter pollution, protect roof material, reduce noise, provide habitat for small animals, improve quality of life, and decrease the urban heat island effect. Green roofs are eligible for energy credit. Green roofs are eligible for energy credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this subsection apply to periods after December 31, 2008, for the credit for residential green roofs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this subsection apply to periods after December 31, 2008, for the credit for residential green roofs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The new paragraph introduces a 30 percent credit for qualified green roof property expenditures, with a limitation of $2,000 for such expenditures. The new paragraph introduces a 30 percent credit for qualified green roof property expenditures, with a limitation of $2,000 for such expenditures. Qualified green roof property expenditure refers to an expenditure for a green roof installed on a US residence by the taxpayer, with specific criteria for what constitutes a qualified green roof. The amendment introduces a 30 percent credit for qualified green roof property expenditures, with a maximum limit of $2,000. The credit is allowed against alternative minimum tax and has specific criteria for what qualifies as a green roof property expenditure. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for a taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart and section 27. Unused credit can be carried forward in certain circumstances. The credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year if it exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a)(2) or paragraph (1) for the current taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include section 25D for tax credits. Amendments are made to sections 23, 24, 25B, and 26 to incorporate the new section 25D. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this subsection apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2008, in taxable years ending after that date. The amendments are subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001.
